title: Upstate New York Foundry to Mend Damaged ‘Charging Bull’ Sculpture
text:
An upstate New York foundry has been retained to repair the “Charging Bull,” the iconic bronze bull sculpture near Wall Street that was damaged over the weekend when a man smashed a metal banjo over its head.

The Bowling Green Association, a business alliance located near the statue, said the foundry, Polich Tallix, was expected to examine the bull later this week, but the cost of repair has already been estimated at $15,000.

Arthur Piccolo, chairman of the association, said that the sculpture’s creator, Arturo Di Modica, had hired Polich Tallix to fix the sculpture’s head. Repairs won’t begin until Mr. Di Modica arrives in New York from Sicily at the end of the month to personally oversee the restoration, said Mr. Piccolo.

The statue, which is 16 feet long and weighs about 7,000 pounds, will likely be repaired over the course of several days at its current location on Broadway in lower Manhattan, just blocks from the New York Stock Exchange.

Damage to the ‘Charging Bull’ will be repaired on site near Wall Street. Photo: Craig Ruttle/Associated Press

“Our intent is to leave it on site and do the repairs here,” Mr. Piccolo said. “Luckily, the damage is not as severe as it could’ve been.”

New York City Police Department officials said that 43-year-old Tevon Varlack began bashing the sculpture around noon on Saturday, striking it multiple times as a crowd gathered around him. His motivations were unclear, the officials said.

Mr. Varlack was arrested and charged with criminal mischief and disorderly conduct, according to court records. A judge released him without bail. Mr. Varlack, who faces up to a year in prison, is scheduled to appear in court again on Oct. 21.

Mr. Varlack, who lives in Houston, didn’t respond to requests for comment.

Though the bull is listed on the Parks Department’s website as a permanent monument, a Parks Department spokeswoman said the agency won’t be paying for the repairs. Mr. Piccolo said that Mr. Di Modica will pay for the repairs himself if necessary.

The sculpture angered executives of the New York Stock Exchange when it was initially placed in front of the exchange without permission in December 1989. After the exchange paid to have it removed, Mr. Di Modica worked with the Parks Department to have it reinstalled a few blocks away on Broadway, where it has remained.

Others have left their mark on the bull in the past. It has twice been doused with blue paint, and in 2010 an artist covered the sculpture in a coat made of yarn, a type of graffiti known as “yarn bombing.”

What separated Saturday’s incident from the rest, art world experts said, was the violence of the act. Fernando Luis Alvarez, who runs an art gallery that has worked with Mr. Di Modica in the past, said that the yarn stunt was intriguing because it didn’t damage the sculpture.

“But vandalism is different. Vandalism takes it to a whole different level,” he said.
